Award.AwardTitle: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Measuring the Impact of the Re-entry of Ride Sourcing in Austin, Texas: A Natural Experiment

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Approximately one year after suspending services in Austin following the defeat of Proposition 1, Uber and Lyft relaunched ridesharing services in Austin on May 29, 2017. Services resumed in response to Texas House bill 100, which created a statewide regulatory framework for transportation network companies that superseded local ordinances. In response to this development, this Grants for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) collaborative research project will analyze changes to travel behavior after a service disruption has ended. The project represents a unique natural experiment to measure the impact of these services on city infrastructure and the economy. The motivating research question is, "How does the restoration of ride-sourcing services impact travel behavior particularly with regards to number of trips, mode choice and vehicle ownership". A comparative case is provided by the collapse and subsequent reconstruction of the I-35W Bridge in Minneapolis, Minnesota, in which a 25 percent reduction in usage was seen following opening of a replacement bridge.

This project will design and implement a travel survey of ride-sourcing passengers in order to quantify the impact on travel behavior as a result of Uber and Lyft restoring ridesharing services in Austin, TX. The survey will utilize a non-random, opt-in sampling methodology, to be administered over an approximate two-month period. The survey data will not be weighted or expanded, as the full universe of former ridesharing passengers is not known. Expected research results have the potential to capture adaptations by passengers and organizations in response to service restoration. The results are also expected to inform ongoing discussions on the impact of similar events on mobility in other cities. Methods for data coding as well as the data themselves will be made available to support subsequent research.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
On May 7, 2016, residents of Austin, Texas, voted against Proposition 1, which would have allowed ridesourcing/transportation networking companies (TNCs) to continue using their own background check systems. The defeat of the proposition prompted Uber and Lyft to suspend services in Austin indefinitely. The disruption provided for a natural experiment to evaluate the impact of Uber and Lyft on users’ travel demand and the supply side implications of the entry of new players. In examining the impact, the team of researchers conducted an online survey that combines stated and revealed preference questions (N=1,840) of former Uber and/or Lyft users in Austin to explore the effect of the disruption on travel behavior.

The resulting analyses revealed several key findings, including the following:

  • Forty five percent of the surveyed population switched to the use of personal vehicles after disruption. Three percent shifted to public transit.
  • Individuals who switched to personal vehicles also include 8.9% of respondents who reported purchasing a vehicle in response to the service disruption.
  • Individuals who switched to a personal vehicle increased his or her probability of a higher trip frequency post disruption by 14%.
  • The probability of a higher trip frequency for individuals who were satisfied with the quality of Uber and Lyft services pre-disruption however decreased from 21% to 6%.

On May 29, 2017, Texas Governor Abbot signed House Bill 100, which established a statewide regulatory framework, less burdensome than that which was established through the local referendums that drove Uber and Lyft out of Austin. The newly signed legislation “requires ride-hailing companies to have a permit from the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation and pay an annual fee of $5,000 to operate throughout the state. It also calls for companies to perform local, state and national criminal background checks on drivers annually — but doesn't require drivers to be fingerprinted” In response to the adoption of House Bill 100, Uber and Lyft resumed services in Austin the day the legislation was signed.

To evaluate the impact of Uber and Lyft’s return on regional travel behavior, the research team conducted a follow up web survey of Austin region residents. The survey was largely based on the initial web survey methodology.  The number of responses (N=113) was much lower. The Phase 2 survey methodology was based on that of Phase 1  The following bullets present a brief summary of the key survey findings, many of which are consistent with the Phase 1 survey findings.

  • Prior to the suspension, a majority of respondents reported using four separate TNCs for trips beginning in the city of Austin, with Uber and Lyft characterize by the highest use.
  • More than three of four respondent had used either Uber or Lyft for trips beginning in the City of Austin prior to the suspension.
  • The most prevalent reference trip purposes were social or recreational trips OR trips to or from the airport.
  • Sixty percent of respondents that used Uber/Lyft to make the reference trip (pre suspension) reported decreased usage of TNC during the suspension. Once Uber/Lyft resumed services, a plurality (46 percent) reported increased usage of TNCs, relative to their use during the suspension. Forty percent reported same levels of TNC usage.
  • More than four of ten respondents that used Uber/Lyft to make the reference trip (pre suspension) reported being extremely inconvenienced by the suspension of Uber/Lyft services. Two thirds reported that Uber and Lyft resuming services was extremely useful.
  • Across all three periods (pre suspension, suspension and post suspension), trip origin times stayed consistent, with the highest proportion of trips beginning in the late afternoon and early evening (5pm-10pm).
  • Across all three periods, the mean trip cost decreased from a pre-suspension high of $15.37 to a post suspension low of $11.38. The median trip cost remained consistent across the pre-suspension and suspension periods ($12.00), but decreased to $8.70 during the post-suspension period. This cost decrease is further supported by findings suggesting that 27 percent of post suspension TNC users reported discounts on their reference trip taken via TNC.
  • During the suspension, a majority (51 percent) of respondents transitioned from Uber/Lyft to a personal vehicle to make the reference trip most frequently. Twenty-two percent transitioned to another TNC, and 3 percent transitioned to public transportation. With the exception of 3 percent who entirely stopped making the reference trip, the balance transitioned to some other mode (bike, car share, walk, taxi or ride from a friend). Following the resumption of Uber/Lyft services, 72% reported using a TNC for the reference trip most frequently. Ten percent used a personal vehicle and 2 percent reported using public transportation. Twelve percent reported using some other mode most frequently to make the reference trip.

 


Last Modified: 08/10/2018
Modified by: Robert C Hampshire
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: On May 7, 2016, residents of Austin, Texas, voted against Proposition 1, which would have allowed ridesourcing/transportation networking companies (TNCs) to continue using their own background check systems. The defeat of the proposition prompted Uber and Lyft to suspend services in Austin indefinitely. The disruption provided for a natural experiment to evaluate the impact of Uber and Lyft on users? travel demand and the supply side implications of the entry of new players. In examining the impact, the team of researchers conducted an online survey that combines stated and revealed preference questions (N=1,840) of former Uber and/or Lyft users in Austin to explore the effect of the disruption on travel behavior. The resulting analyses revealed several key findings, including the following: Forty five percent of the surveyed population switched to the use of personal vehicles after disruption. Three percent shifted to public transit. Individuals who switched to personal vehicles also include 8.9% of respondents who reported purchasing a vehicle in response to the service disruption. Individuals who switched to a personal vehicle increased his or her probability of a higher trip frequency post disruption by 14%. The probability of a higher trip frequency for individuals who were satisfied with the quality of Uber and Lyft services pre-disruption however decreased from 21% to 6%. On May 29, 2017, Texas Governor Abbot signed House Bill 100, which established a statewide regulatory framework, less burdensome than that which was established through the local referendums that drove Uber and Lyft out of Austin. The newly signed legislation "requires ride-hailing companies to have a permit from the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation and pay an annual fee of $5,000 to operate throughout the state. It also calls for companies to perform local, state and national criminal background checks on drivers annually — but doesn't require drivers to be fingerprinted" In response to the adoption of House Bill 100, Uber and Lyft resumed services in Austin the day the legislation was signed. To evaluate the impact of Uber and Lyft?s return on regional travel behavior, the research team conducted a follow up web survey of Austin region residents. The survey was largely based on the initial web survey methodology. The number of responses (N=113) was much lower. The Phase 2 survey methodology was based on that of Phase 1 The following bullets present a brief summary of the key survey findings, many of which are consistent with the Phase 1 survey findings. Prior to the suspension, a majority of respondents reported using four separate TNCs for trips beginning in the city of Austin, with Uber and Lyft characterize by the highest use. More than three of four respondent had used either Uber or Lyft for trips beginning in the City of Austin prior to the suspension. The most prevalent reference trip purposes were social or recreational trips OR trips to or from the airport. Sixty percent of respondents that used Uber/Lyft to make the reference trip (pre suspension) reported decreased usage of TNC during the suspension. Once Uber/Lyft resumed services, a plurality (46 percent) reported increased usage of TNCs, relative to their use during the suspension. Forty percent reported same levels of TNC usage. More than four of ten respondents that used Uber/Lyft to make the reference trip (pre suspension) reported being extremely inconvenienced by the suspension of Uber/Lyft services. Two thirds reported that Uber and Lyft resuming services was extremely useful. Across all three periods (pre suspension, suspension and post suspension), trip origin times stayed consistent, with the highest proportion of trips beginning in the late afternoon and early evening (5pm-10pm). Across all three periods, the mean trip cost decreased from a pre-suspension high of $15.37 to a post suspension low of $11.38. The median trip cost remained consistent across the pre-suspension and suspension periods ($12.00), but decreased to $8.70 during the post-suspension period. This cost decrease is further supported by findings suggesting that 27 percent of post suspension TNC users reported discounts on their reference trip taken via TNC. During the suspension, a majority (51 percent) of respondents transitioned from Uber/Lyft to a personal vehicle to make the reference trip most frequently. Twenty-two percent transitioned to another TNC, and 3 percent transitioned to public transportation. With the exception of 3 percent who entirely stopped making the reference trip, the balance transitioned to some other mode (bike, car share, walk, taxi or ride from a friend). Following the resumption of Uber/Lyft services, 72% reported using a TNC for the reference trip most frequently. Ten percent used a personal vehicle and 2 percent reported using public transportation. Twelve percent reported using some other mode most frequently to make the reference trip.
